act shall control history adopted by on  drinking water source protection  short title and purpose  definitions  establishment of drinking water source protection zones  permitted uses  prohibited uses  administration  short title and purpose the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as the drinking water source protection  the purpose of this chapter is to insure the provision of a safe and sanitary drinking water supply for the city by the establishment of drinking water source protection zones surrounding the wellheads for all wells which are the supply sources for the city water system and by the designation and regulation of property uses and conditions which may be maintained within such zones hmc   definitions when used in this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given in this section design standard means a control which is implemented by a potential contamination source to prevent discharges to the ground water spill protection is an example of a design standard land management strategies means zoning and nonzoning controls which include but are not limited to the following zoning and subdivision ordinances site plan reviews design and operating standards source prohibitions purchase of property and development rights public education programs groundwater monitoring household hazardous waste collection programs water conservation programs memoranda of understanding written contacts and agreements and so forth pollution source means point source discharges of contaminants to groundwater or potential discharges of the liquid forms of extremely hazardous substances which are stored in containers in excess of applicable threshold planning quantities as specified in sara title iii examples of possible pollution sources include but are nor limited to the following storage facilities that store the liquid forms of extremely hazardous substances septic tanks drain fields class v underground injection wells landfills open dumps landfilling of sludge and septage manure piles salt piles pit privies and animal feeding operations with more than ten animal units the following clarify the definition of pollution source animal feeding operation means a lot or facility where the following conditions are met animals have been or will be stabled or confined and fed or maintained for a total of fortyfive days or more in any twelve month period and crops vegetation forage growth or postharvest residues are not sustained in the normal growing season over any portion of the lot or facility two or more animal feeding operations under common ownership are considered to he a single feeding operation if they adjoin each other if they use a common area or if they use a common system for the disposal of wastes animal unit means a unit of measurement for any animal feeding operation calculated by adding the following numbers  the number of slaughter and feeder cattle multiplied by 10 plus the number of mature dairy cattle multiplied by 14 plus the number of swine weighing over fiftyfive pounds multiplied by 04 plus the number of sheep multiplied by 01 plus the number of horses multiplied by 20 extremely hazardous substances means those substances which are identified in the ehs column of the title iii list of lists  consolidated list of chemicals subject to reporting under sara title iii epa 560491011 potential contamination source means any facility or site which employs an activity or procedure which may potentially contaminate ground water a pollution source is also a potential contamination source regulatory agency means any governmental agency with jurisdiction over hazardous waste as defined herein sanitary landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes including putrescible wastes or hazardous wastes are disposed of on land by placing earth cover thereon septic tankdrainfield systems means a system which is comprised of a septic tank and a drainfield which accepts domestic wastewater from buildings or facilities for subsurface treatment and disposal by their design septic tankdrainfield system discharges cannot be controlled with design standards wellhead means the upper terminal of a well including adapters ports seals valves and other attachments hmc   establishment of drinking water source protection zones there is established use districts to be known as zones one two three and four of the drinking water source protection area identified and described as follows zone one is the area within a one hundredfoot radius from the wellhead zone two is the area within a two hundred fiftyday groundwater time of travel to the wellhead the boundary of the aquifers which supplies water to the groundwater source or the groundwater divide whichever is closer zone three waiver criteria zone is the area within a threeyear groundwater time of travel to the wellhead or margin of the collection area the boundary of the aquifers which supplies water to the groundwater source or the groundwater divide whichever is closer zone four is the area within a fifteenyear groundwater time of travel to the wellhead the boundary of the aquifers which supplies water to the groundwater source or the groundwater divide whichever is closer hmc   permitted uses the following uses shall be permitted within drinking water source protection zones any use permitted within existing agricultural singlefamily residential multifamily residential and commercial districts so long as uses conform to the rules and regulations of the regulatory agencies any other open land use where any building located on the property is incidental and accessory to the primary open land use hmc   prohibited uses the following uses or conditions shall be and are prohibited within drinking water sources protection zones whether or not such use or condition may otherwise be ordinarily included as a part of a use permitted under zone one the location of potential contamination sources as defined herein unless they are controlled with design standards  zone two the location of a pollution source unless its contaminated discharges can be controlled with design standards  zones three and four the location of a potential contamination source unless it can be controlled management strategies hmc     administration the policies and procedures for administration of any source protection zone established under this chapter including without limitation those applicable to nonconforming uses exception enforcement and penalties shall be the same as provided in the existing zoning chapter for the city as the same is presently enacted or may from time to time be amended hmc  wireless telecommunications facilities  summary  purpose of provisions  application  definitions  special antennas and energy equipment  satellite dishes  wind conversion  solar equipment  wireless telecommunications facilities  telecommunication facility justification study and master plan required  master plan requirements  telecommunication facility justification study requirements  permitted uses  technical necessity exceptionconditional uses  equipment facilities  historic sites  antennas not permitted  business license requirement  nonmaintained or abandoned facilities  building permits  wireless telecommunications facilities illustrations  summary  purpose of provisions this chapter addresses planning issues resulting from the rapid growth in demand for low power radio services this chapter distinguishes low power radio services from other broadcasting type telecommunication technologies and establishes provisions that deal with issues of demand visual mitigation noise engineering residential impacts health safety and facility siting it is the intent of this provision to protect the aesthetic viewshed within highland city to promote more antennas that use stealth design and technology and to specifically restrict monopoles with typical array antenna construction wherever possible hmc   application the requirements of this chapter apply to both commercial and private low power radio services such as cellular or pcs personal communications system communications and paging systems all facilities shall comply with the following regulations and all other ordinances of the city and any pertinent regulations of the federal communications commission and the federal aviation administration hmc   definitions the following definitions are specific to this chapter antenna means any system of wires poles rods arms reflecting discs or similar devices of various sizes materials and shapes including but not limited to solid or wiremesh dish horn spherical or bar configuration used for the transmission or reception of radio signals types of antennas include roof mounted antenna an antenna or series of individual antennas mounted directly to a flat roof of a building mechanical penthouse or parapet enclosure wall which is on the roof top of a building tophat antenna a spatial array of antennas generally located on a freestanding structure where the visible width of antennas and antenna mounting structures are more than two feet in width as viewed looking directly at the structure utility pole antennas any antenna mounted directly to a street light pole this definition shall not include poles carrying electrical lines telephone lines or any other type of utility not specifically included above wall mounted antenna any antenna or series of individual antennas mounted directly to the fascia or outside vertical wall of a structure existing parapet walls penthouses or mechanical equipment rooms with no portion of the antenna extending above the roofline of such structures whip antenna an antenna that is cylindrical in shape whip antennas can be directional or omnidirectional and vary in size depending upon the frequency and gain for which they are designed antenna support structure means a structure the principle purpose of which is for location of antennas types of antenna support structures include monopole a free standing antenna support structure placed directly on the ground used to support one or more antennas lattice tower a selfsupporting multiple sided open steel frame structure used to support one or more antennas colocation means a telecommunications facility comprising more than one telecommunications providers antennas equipment facility means any building shelter or cabinet used by telecommunication providers to house switching backup or other equipment at a telecommunications facility lattice tower means a selfsupporting multiple sides open steel frame structure used to support telecommunications equipment low power radio services facility means an unmanned structure which consists of equipment used primarily for the transmission reception or transfer of voice or data wave or wireless transmissions such sites typically require the construction of transmission support structures to which antenna equipment is attached monopole means a single cylindrical antenna support structure that acts as a support structure for antennas monopole with antennas and antenna support structure greater than two feet in width means a selfsupporting monopole tower on which antennas or antenna support structures exceeding two feet in diameter from the center of the pole are placed the antennas and antenna support structures may not exceed thirteen feet in width or eight feet in height monopole with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width means a selfsupporting monopole tower on which antennae or antenna support structures not exceeding two feet in width are placed antennas and antenna support structures may not exceed ten feet in height nonstealth design means any antenna or equipment facility not camouflaged in a manner to blend with surrounding land uses features or architecture the design does not conceal the intended use of the telecommunications facility a monopole with equipment facilities above ground and unscreened would be considered nonstealth an antenna with a top hat or triangle array exceeding two feet in diameter from the center of pole would be considered nonstealth residential institutional use means a school church clubhouse or public building in a residential zone this definition does not include residences or multifamily structures containing one or more residential units stealth means antennas antenna support structures and equipment facilities camouflaged or designed to blend with surrounding land uses features and architecture thus minimizing the aesthetic impact on adjacent uses thereby concealing the intended use and appearance of the telecommunications facility such as heavy landscaping installing telecommunications facilities within existing buildings or placing equipment facilities underground the following uses shall be considered as stealth antennas wall mount antenna a flush wall mount antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the antenna is painted the same color as the background  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached flag pole antenna a flag pole antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features a pole with all antennae and their associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole  and a pole that is bronze in material or color or a pole that is painted to blend with the visual surroundings  and a pole that has a maximum radius at grade of two feet and a maximum radius at peak of twelve inches  and a pole that includes an american flag in proportion to the flag pole height  and the associative equipment is less than twelve cubic feet in size maximum of three feet in height and landscaped or located within an adjacent building  and a pole that includes a cap at peak typically associated with a flag pole  and a pole that includes lighting for the american flag that is illuminated moderately and subdued according to the surrounding uses dormer antenna a dormer antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the antenna is designed to be architecturally consistent with the existing building the antenna will be located on  and the dormer does not project above the roofline of the building it is located on  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached chimney antenna a chimney antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the antenna is designed to be architecturally consistent with the existing building the antenna will be located on  and the chimney does not project more than three feet above the roofline of the building it is located on  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside  and the antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached landscape antenna a landscape antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the antenna is designed to be consistent in height shape and color with the local biome or geographically surrounding and immediately adjacent environment rocks trees where the antenna will be located  and the area around the base of the antenna is revegetated with native planting  and the associated equipment is camouflaged similar to the antenna or buried light pole antenna a light pole antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features a pole that is located within a city park and adjacent to a sport field with additionally planned or constructed light poles  and a pole with all antennae and their associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole  and a pole that is consistent in material to adjacent light poles within the same park  and a pole that has a maximum radius at grade of 2 feet and a maximum radius at peak of twelve inches  and a pole that includes lighting facilities approved by the city consistent with park lighting and sufficient for the use intended  and the associative equipment is less than 12 cubic feet in size maximum of 3 feet in height and landscaped or located within an existing park facility building  and the applicant increases the size of a pavilion restroom or other similar park facility if the equipment requires a larger facility if the new facility meets all zoning and other city requirements associated with a park or the modified structure truss antenna a truss antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the antenna is located entirely within the roof of an existing building  and the antenna does not project outside of the building it is located within  and the antenna is located within a building where the equipment facility is located inside  and the antenna is located within a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached high power transmission line antenna a high power transmission line antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the pole shall be considered a high power transmission line carrier for the local power company and shall be constructed of galvanized metal and painted to blend as much as possible with the surroundings  and a pole with all associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole  and a pole that is painted to blend with the visual surroundings  and all antennas shall be less than 18 inches from the surface of the pole  and the associative equipment is less than 12 cubic feet in size maximum of 3 feet in height and landscaped or buried or located within an adjacent building colocation antenna a high power transmission line antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features the original initial installation received a conditional use permit  and the new facility shall comply with all other provisions relating to site development landscaping security etc as provided herein and the conditions required for the original facility  and the new antennas and antenna structure shall not exceed eighteen inches from the surface of the existing monopole  and the equipment for the new antenna shall be enclosed within a masonry shelter or an existing building  and the new antenna wiring conduit and power supply shall not be exposed above the roofline of the new or existing structure telecommunications facility means an unmanned structure which consists of equipment including antennas antenna support structures and equipment facilities as defined herein that transmit andor receive voice andor data communications signals such as cellular or pcs personal communications system communications and paging systems hmc   special antennas and energy equipment special antennas and energy equipment shall include satellite dishes wind power conversion facilities and solar power facilities hmc   satellite dishes earth station any apparatus or device commonly known as an earth terminal antennae earth terminal satellite communication antennae satellite antennae microwave dish antennae satellite television antennae or dish antennae which is designed for the purpose of transmitting andor receiving radio television satellite microwave or other electromagnetic energy signals but does not include conventional television radio and amateur radio antennae earth station regulations shall apply to earth stations with a dish diameter over four feet in size earth stations with a dish diameter under four feet in size shall be regulated in the same manner as television antennas location of earth stations over four feet in diameter in residential zones ground mounted in all residential zones maximum height maximum height from grade to the top of the dish shall be twelve feet any ground mounted earth station with a height exceeding twelve feet shall be allowed only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission number per lot a maximum of one earth station structure shall exist at any one time on any residentially zoned property front yard if there is no other alternative for the location earth stations may be allowed in the front yard area only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission setback maximums from the public street shall be determined by the planning commission and applicants shall provide a site plan indicating the location of the earth station rear and side yards earth stations shall be located in rear yards where possible if rear yards are not acceptable for proper reception of signals the earth station may be located in either side yard on corner lots the earth station may be situated to the rear of the main dwelling and within the area between the main building and street when approved by the planning commission as a conditional use easements rightsofway no earth station shall be located on any legally recorded public utility easement or rightofway multifamily one earth station shall be allowed per building a second earth station may be allowed with a conditional use approval from the planning commission roof mounted in all residential zones approval if the rear and side yards are deemed unacceptable for suitable signal reception then roof mounted earth stations may be permitted with a conditional use review and approval from the planning commission such roof installations may be permitted by the planning commission under the following criteria roof mounted earth stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary structure and shall not be mounted upon appurtenances such as chimneys towers trees poles or spires an earth station shall not exceed a height determined appropriate by the planning commission the height of the structure shall not exceed the maximum height limits established within the zone in which the earth station is to be located evidence of wind loading and structural safety of the earth station shall be provided to the planning commission by the applicants an earth station mounted on a roof shall be located on the portion of the roof which is oriented to the rear yard rather than located on the portion of the roof visible from the street location of earth stations over four feet in diameter in commercial and industrial zones ground mounted in commercial and industrial zones maximum height maximum height from grade to the top of the dish shall be fifteen feet any earth station with a height exceeding fifteen feet shall be allowed only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission number allowed two earth station structures shall be permitted at any one time per separate commercial or industrial business more than two earth stations may be permitted with a conditional use approval from the planning commission advertising no earth station shall display lettering or numbers for advertising purposes rear and side yards an earth station in any commercial or industrial shall be located in the rear or side yard area if possible front yards an earth station may be located in the front yard provided the structure is not located in the minimum front landscape area and the structure does not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic easements rightsofway no earth station shall be located on any legally recorded public utility easement or rightofway roof mounted in all commercial and industrial zones approval if the front rear and side yards are deemed unacceptable for suitable signal reception or pose a negative aesthetic or neighborhood impact then roof mounted earth stations may be permitted with conditional use review and approval from the planning commission such roof installations may be permitted under the following criteria roof mounted earth stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary structure and shall not be mounted upon appurtenances such as chimneys towers trees poles which exceed the minimum height of mast required to mount the antennae to the roof spires or similar structures the height of a roof mounted earth station located in any commercial or industrial shall not exceed twelve feet above the highest point of the roof upon which the structure is located height increases over twelve feet may be approved by the planning commission as deemed appropriate the roof mounted earth station shall not exceed the maximum height limits established within the zone in which the earth station is to be located other criteria as deemed appropriate by the planning commission all roof mounted earth stations shall be screened from view from adjacent streets and properties in the same manner as is required of all other roof mounted equipment in this development code said station shall not significantly change the architectural character of the structure hmc   wind conversion wind energy conversion systems shall meet the following standards minimum tower setback from any property line shall equal the height of the tower towers shall meet main dwelling setbacks for the particular zone in which the tower is located there shall be sufficient safety measures to prevent the tower from becoming a climbing hazard the tower shall not be located on a utility easement or rightofway in the case of joint ownership of a tower the structure may be located on any lots as approved by the chief building official providing the tower meets setback requirements mentioned above in respect to all perimeter properties the owner shall obtain a building permit and certification by a registered engineer as to the safety of equipment and installation hmc   solar equipment these regulations shall apply to all solar heating developments private or public to the extent that design review is not preempted by state or federal law review and standards all applications for building permits for structures with solar installations shall be forwarded to the community development department for review and approval the proposed installation will be reviewed to assure compliance with the following standards collectors shall not reflect sunlight into neighboring windows the installation shall extend no higher than roof ridge line or on a flat roof a parapet wall the installation shall stand no more than seven feet above the surface of the roof the color of collector frames shall be compatible with the roof the piping shall blend with the surface to which it is attached the ends of the panel arrays shall be covered and mounting brackets shall blend with the roof and not be visible from front yard planning commission review if a review by the planning commission is considered necessary the development shall be reviewed at a regularly scheduled meeting at the time of the meeting the applicant shall provide the following site plan drawings showing existing building elevations landscaping and screening plans the kind color and texture of materials to be used any other pertinent information determined to be necessary by the director the planning commission shall approve approve with conditions or deny the development or structure hmc   wireless telecommunications facilities facility types low power radio services facilities are characterized by the type or location of the antenna structure there are five general types of such antenna structures wall mounted antennas  roof mounted antennas  monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width  monopoles with antennas and antenna support structures greater than two feet in width  and lattice towers a combination of both roof and wall mounted antennas are allowed on a building the total area for all wall and roof mounted antennas and supporting structures combined shall not exceed forty square feet for each exterior wall of the building or a total of one hundred sixty square feet per building per carrier a maximum of four walls shall be occupied by cellular antennas the total area is the sum of the area of each individual antenna face and the visible portion of the supporting structure as viewed when looking directly at the face of the building the total area for a roof mounted antenna shall apply to the closest exterior wall up to three carriers may utilize each building side for a maximum of four sides each carrier must obtain a separate conditional use permit in no event will wall mounted antennas be allowed on the front of buildings monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width and monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure greater than two feet in width shall be allowed only in the rear yard area these structures shall not be located in a required landscaped area buffer area or required parking area standards for the installation of each type of antenna are as follows wall mounted antenna the following provisions apply to wall mounted antennas wall mounted antennas shall not extend above the wall line of the building and shall not extend more than four feet horizontally from the face of the building antennas equipment and the supporting structures shall be painted to match the color of the building or structure or the background against which they are most commonly seen antennas and the supporting structures on buildings should be architecturally compatible with the building whip antennas are not allowed on a wall mounted antenna structure antennas mounted directly on existing parapet walls penthouses or mechanical equipment rooms with no portion of the antenna extending above the roof line of such structures shall be considered a wall mounted antenna roof mounted antenna the following provisions apply to roof mounted antennas roof mounted antennas shall be allowed on top of existing penthouse or mechanical equipment room the antennas shall be mounted at least five feet from the exterior wall of a building for antennas mounted between five and ten feet from the exterior wall the maximum height of a roof mounted antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the exterior wall up to a maximum height of ten feet above the roof line of the building to which the antenna is attached antennas shall be mounted at least five feet behind a parapet wall for antennas mounted between five and ten feet behind a parapet wall the maximum height of the antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the wall up to a maximum of ten feet as measured from the top of the parapet wall roof mounted antennas are permitted only on a flat roof and shall be screened constructed andor colored to match the structure to which they are attached monopole with antennas and antenna support structures less than two feet in width the total antenna structure mounted on a monopole shall not exceed two feet in width the maximum height of such antenna shall not exceed ten feet in height all monopoles shall be located a minimum distance equal to one and onehalf times the height of the monopole from an existing legal building lot monopole with antennas and antenna support structure greater than two feet in width the maximum visible dimensions of antennas and antenna mounting structures shall not exceed thirteen feet as viewed looking directly at the monopole at the same elevation as the antennas and antenna mounting structure all monopoles shall be located a minimum distance equal to one and onehalf times the height of the monopole from an existing legal building lot nor within two hundred feet of sr 92 and sr 74 as designated gateway thoroughfares of the city hmc   telecommunication facility justification study and master plan required a master plan for each company shall be submitted additionally a complete application and telecommunication facility justification study shall be submitted by each company for each proposed telecommunications facility the telecommunication facility justification study and master plan shall be submitted to the community development department which will provide a preliminary review upon completion of the community development department review the telecommunication facility justification study and master plan will be scheduled with the development committee for approval if permitted or further review and recommendation to the planning commission if conditional or technical necessity exception together with a complete application hmc   master plan requirements a master plan shall be completed by each company the master plan shall show proposed locations of future telecommunication facilities and include the rationale for each potential telecommunication facility maps shall be utilized to graphically illustrate the coverage radius of each potential telecommunication facility hmc   telecommunication facility justification study requirements a telecommunication facility justification study shall be completed for each telecommunication facility by the wireless provider wireless telecommunication facility review committee wtfrc the applicant shall first submit a complete application for a wireless telecommunication facility to the community development director a minimum of two weeks prior to the next available development review committee meeting for a preliminary review by the wtfrc the wtfrc shall consist of the city administrator city engineer and community development director if the applicant has submitted all of the required information for a wireless telecommunications facility and it does not require a technical necessity exceptionconditional use the wtfrc may grant approval for a proposed wireless telecommunication facility if the application is determined to qualify as a permitted use per this ordinance the wtfrc may require additional conditions if the proposed antenna or associated equipment shelter is exposed the wtfrc may impose additional conditions on a permitted use consistent with a conditional use application such as landscaping technical exception required if it is determined that the proposed application requires a technical necessityconditional use per the ordinance the applicant will be required to submit a new and complete application consistent with conditional use procedure highland city development to being placed on the planning commission for a public hearing and recommendation the city council shall be the legislative body to consider any application considered a technical exceptionconditional use the telecommunication facility justification study required from all applicants and for every application requesting a wireless telecommunication facility shall include the following information rationale the rationale for the selection of the proposed telecommunication facility in view of the relative merits of any feasible alternative telecommunication facilities within the search ring the telecommunication facility justification study shall include a description of the telecommunication facility a description of the telecommunications facilities proposed to be placed on the location with technical reasons for their design and efforts made to minimize impacts on the surrounding land uses a listing of other telecommunication facilities within the search ring which were evaluated and a statement of reasons why the final location was chosen staff may request the search ring and propagation information for the proposed telecommunication facilities the applicant shall justify that the telecommunications facilities comply with the highland city general plan as well as the required setback height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are proposed to be located colocation the study shall also examine the potential for colocation at an existing or the proposed telecommunication facility if colocation is not possible at an existing telecommunication facility or if the proposed new telecommunication facility is not available for colocation then the applicant shall include a written explanation why colocation is not possible height the height of the antennas and antenna support structures shall be justified detailed written analysis that explains in nontechnical terms the reasons why service cannot be effectively provided unless at the requested height if the proposed telecommunication facility is a roof mount or wall mount the city may request that the study verify that the existing or proposed screening will screen from view all telecommunications facilities equipment facilities the study must include a detailed written explanation and analysis not limited to fiscal reasons alone of the potential for the equipment facilities to be either 1 located in an existing building or 2 designed using stealth design technology or other visual screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facilities visual analysis the applicant shall submit a visual analysis which may include photo simulation field mock up or other techniques which identifies the potential for visual impacts of the proposed telecommunications facility the analysis shall consider views from public areas streets parks etc and from private residences the analysis shall assess the cumulative impacts of the proposed telecommunications facility and other existing or approved telecommunications facilities in the area as provided by city staff and shall identify all mitigation measures consistent with the technical aspects and requirements of the proposed telecommunications facility all costs associated with this requirement are to be borne by the applicant independent review the city may if it deems necessary cause each telecommunications facility to be reviewed by a qualified radio frequency engineer the purpose of the review is to determine if other locations are available to achieve an equivalent signal distribution and not significantly affect the operation of the telecommunications facility such a review may be required when an applicant indicates that no other acceptable location exists the costs shall be borne by the applicant hmc   permitted uses the following telecommunications facilities are classified as permitted use any request for telecommunications facilities differing from the standards as allowed in this section shall require a technical necessity exception from the planning commission and city council all telecommunications facilities must comply with the highland city general plan as well as the required setback height and landscaping requirements of the zone in which they are to be located and are subject to all provisions for site plan review including modifications to existing site plans all permitted use equipment facilities listed in this section must be 1 located inside of an existing building or 2 designed using stealth design technology or other visual screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facilities city property telecommunications facilities located on highland cityowned property are allowed as a permitted use provided the facilities meet the standards as specified for each type of facility as contained in this section and the facility owner has entered into a leasetype agreement with the city wall mounted antenna wall mounted antennas which comply with the following standards are allowed as a permitted use locations located on a parcel in a commercial municipal or professional office zone on a commercial municipal or office structure or in residential zones on residential institutional uses mounting method wall mounted antennas shall not extend above the wall line of the building or extend more than four feet horizontally from the face of the building stealth design antennas equipment facilities and the antenna support structure shall be constructed with stealth design to match the color of the building or structure and to be architecturally compatible with the building or to match the color of the background against which they are most commonly seen area limitations the wall mounted antenna shall comply with area limitations for wall and roof mounted antennas roof mounted antenna roof mounted antennas which comply with the following standards are permitted uses locations located on a parcel in a commercial municipal or professional office zone on a commercial municipal or office structure or in residential zones on residential institutional uses mounting location roof mounted antennas may be located on top of existing penthouses or mechanical equipment rooms provided the telecommunications facilities are enclosed by a structure that creates a visual screen the screening structure and telecommunications facilities shall not extend more than eight feet above the existing roofline of the penthouse or mechanical equipment room for roof mounted antennas not mounted on a penthouse or mechanical equipment room the telecommunications facilities shall be mounted at least five feet from any exterior wall of a building for antennas mounted between five and ten feet from the exterior wall the maximum height of a roof mounted antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the exterior wall up to a maximum height of ten feet above the roofline of the building to which the antenna is attached telecommunications facilities shall be mounted at least five feet behind any parapet wall for antennas mounted between five and ten feet behind a parapet wall the maximum height of the antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the wall up to a maximum of ten feet as measured from the top of the parapet wall screening roof mounted telecommunications facilities shall be located only on a flat roof and shall be screened constructed andor colored to match the structure to which they are attached area limitations for wall and roof mounted antennas a combination of both roof and wall mounted antennas are allowed on a building the total area for all wall and roof mounted antennas and antenna support structures combined shall not exceed forty square feet for each exterior wall of the building or a total of one hundred sixty square feet per building per carrier a maximum of four walls may be occupied by antennas the total area is the sum of the area of each individual antenna face and the visible portion of the antenna support structure and the equipment facility as viewed when looking directly at the face of the building the total area for a roof mounted antenna shall apply to the closest exterior wall up to three carriers may utilize each building side for a maximum of four sides as a permitted use colocation colocation of antennas on an existing monopole is a permitted use provided the antennas do not extend more than twelve inches from the monopole and meet all the provisions as stated in landscaping fencing and safety and equipment facilities stealth design telecommunications facilities that incorporate stealth design technology as defined by this ordinance and are located on a parcel in a commercial or professional office zone or in a residential zone a on property of an existing residential institutional use or public open space or park property shall be considered as a permitted use conversion conversion of flagpoles light standards athletic field lights or other similar structures provided the structures height is not increased more than ten feet or the height is a maximum of forty feet for a new facility shall be considered as a permitted use if the minimum specifications for these uses are met flags and lighting facilities associated with conversion antennas shall be consistent in scale and material with the height and mass of the pole lighting associated with conversion antennas shall not be installed to be directed toward existing residential property lighting shall be entirely controlled and operated by the property owner of the ground the pole is located on ie city school all antennas and associated cables shall be installed entirely within the pole and buried underground flag poles shall be capped with a typical ornament associated with flag poles at a scale consistent with the top of the pole utility pole antennas utility pole antennas which comply with the following standards are permitted uses location utility pole antennas may only be located on existing utility poles method of mounting such antennas shall be designed and installed by the applicant according to the citys specifications and details for utility poles agreement consistent with the use of public rights of way by other utility and cable providers each telecommunication provider is required to enter into an agreement with the city prior to installing any telecommunication facilities in the rights of way the planning commission shall review site plan conditions prior to the execution of the agreement hmc   technical necessity exceptionconditional uses if an applicant cannot meet the standards for telecommunications facilities as provided for in permitted uses for technical reasons an applicant may request a technical necessity exception under the conditional use process if an applicant cannot or will not meet those standards for reasons other than technical reasons the use is not allowed telecommunications facilities which meet the following standards shall be considered for a technical necessity exception and shall be approved conditional use process comply with the highland city general plan as well as the required setback height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are located an applicant cannot meet the standards for telecommunication facilities as provided in permitted uses for technical reasons monopoles are not allowed in any zone within the city without a technical necessity exception being granted by the city council conditional use process following are the minimum standards for a monopole to qualify for a technical necessity exceptionconditional use the planning commission and city council may impose additional requirements as defined in this ordinance if the city is the property owner the city may impose additional requirements at its discretion as part of a lease agreement between property owner and service provider independent review all applications requesting a monopole under the technical necessity exception provision shall complete an independent radio frequency engineering review of the proposed monopole telecommunication facility in relation to the 1 requested height 2 alternative locations 3 other proposed telecommunication facilities and 4 existing telecommunication facilities within highland city the cost of the independent review shall be borne by the applicant antenna sizing the maximum visible width of antennas and antenna support structures on a monopole shall not exceed eight feet in height or three feet in width as viewed looking directly at the monopole at same elevation as the antennas and antenna support structure and do not exceed a perpendicular distance of twentyfour inches from the surface of the pole top hat design is not permitted location and minimum setbacks monopoles shall be allowed only in the rear yard area of any commercial lot which contains a commercial use or on city property these structures shall not be located in a required landscaped area buffer area or required parking area no such antenna shall be located within one hundred sixtyfive feet of a residential property line height limit monopoles shall not project higher than twenty feet above the average building height to a maximum of sixty feet or if there are no buildings within three hundred feet these facilities shall not project higher than ten feet above the average tree canopy height to a maximum of sixty feet measured from ground level landscaping fencing and safety ground surrounding monopoles shall at minimum be landscaped a minimum of two square feet per linear foot of the height of the pole if there are no buildings immediately adjacent to the monopole and equipment facilities all monopoles and equipment facilities shall be surrounded by dense tree growth to screen views of the facility in all directions these trees may be existing on the subject property or planted on subject property the planning commission may require additional landscaping or fencing as part of the site plan approval and conditional use process the climbing pegs shall be removed from the lower twenty feet of the monopole the applicant shall resubmit each telecommunication facility which has been granted a technical necessity exceptionconditional use for review each year for seven years from the date of final approval as established by the city council as part of the conditional use approval process at the time of this review the applicant shall provide information to show that the telecommunications facility is still necessary at the approved location employs the most current available technological advances and that it has been in compliance with all the requirements established by this ordinance and the city council additional conditional use requirements in addition to conditional use standards outlined herein the following factors shall be considered by the planning commission andor city council compatibility of the proposed structure with the height and mass of existing buildings and utility structures  whether colocation of the antenna on other existing structures in the same vicinity such as other towers buildings water towers utility poles athletic field lights parking lot lights etc is possible without significantly impacting antenna transmission or reception  the location of the antenna in relation to existing vegetation topography and buildings to obtain the best visual screening  whether the spacing between monopoles creates quantifiable detrimental impacts to adjoining properties  the planning commission andor city council may reduce the required setback from a residential zone if practical difficulties are demonstrated by the applicant ie city park location public buildings etc or upon detailed demonstration by the applicant that the proposed facility can be effectively screened from the view of nearby sensitive land uses  provided that no pole may be permitted closer than one and onehalf times the height of the pole to any residential dwelling  all antenna locations shall provide assurance that the installation complies with all applicable standards and regulations including but not limited to uniform building national electric codes federal communication commission federal aviation administration and environmental agency as well as all other city ordinances each application for a permit to build a communications tower shall be certified by a licensed professional engineer that the design meets all standards herein no communication facility shall encroach upon or block vehicular or pedestrian access at any time climbing pegs or access ladders shall be removed from the lower twenty feet regardless of location antennas shall be mounted with such standards that the structure can easily withstand wind force up to eighty miles per hour height limit in all cases the maximum height limit for single user monopoles is sixty feet in all cases the maximum height limit for multiple user monopoles is eighty feet each pole location requires a separate technical exceptionconditional use permit hmc   equipment facilities all equipment facilities shall be 1 located in an existing building 2 buried or 3 designed whereby the incorporation of stealth design technology or other screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facility all power lines on the lot leading to the telecommunication facility shall be underground if the applicant can not utilize stealth technology and bury the power lines for the proposed antenna then the applicant shall be required to apply for a technical exceptionconditional use permit the city council shall require the applicant to place the equipment facility underground within an existing building or within a brick or stone shelter if an existing building is within the reasonable vicinity of the proposed antenna and the equipment will not fit within the existing building then the council shall require the applicant to modify the existing building using the same materials and architecture to provide room for the equipment however any modification shall meet all existing zoning ordinances and building codes in addition the city council may require the telecommunications facility area to be fenced with a six foot vinyl coated chainlink fence or other fencing such as masonry concrete or wrought iron a higher quality fence shall be required if it is determined by the city council that a higher quality fence is more consistent with any adjacent developed property or existing fencing in addition the city council shall require landscaping that shall conceal a minimum of fifty percent of the exterior fence to screen the equipment facility while allowing equal visibility for security accessory buildings to antenna structures must comply with the required setback height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are located there shall be no climbing pegs located on the lower twenty feet of the monopole all power lines on the lot leading to the accessory buildings and antenna structure shall be underground hmc   historic sites any telecommunications facility proposed for a location within a historic or on a landmark site is not permitted hmc   antennas not permitted the following telecommunications facilities are not allowed in any zone lattice towers whip antennas on wallmounted support structures top hat antennas any telecommunications facility not specifically listed in the permitted use subsection or not in compliance with the requirements for a technical necessity exceptionconditional use hmc   business license requirement separate use each separate pole or tower and each separate antenna assembly on a given pole or tower shall be considered as a separate use and an annual business license shall be required for each such facility revocation of business license failure to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter any applicable chapter of this city or any state or federal law or regulation constitutes grounds to revoke the business license of the facility and the wireless antenna property owner the owner of property where a telecommunication antenna is located on shall obtain a business license for the operation and lease of a telecommunication facility prior to submitting a building permit for the construction of that wireless facility or antenna hmc   nonmaintained or abandoned facilities the community development director may require each nonmaintained or abandoned telecommunication facility to be removed when such a telecommunications facility has not been repaired or put into use by the owner person having control or person receiving benefit of such structure within thirty calendar days after notice of nonmaintenance or abandonment is given to the owner person having control or person receiving the benefit of such structure the city may require a cash or surety bond to guarantee removal of the telecommunications facility to be submitted prior to final site plan approval or issuance of a building permit the bond amount shall be determined upon review by city staff if the structure upon which the antenna is placed including but not limited to utility pole water tank light pole or building is no longer used or is proposed by the owner or operator of that structure to be removed or replaced the antenna must be removed within ninety calendar days after notice from the city any replacement telecommunication facility if necessary is required to comply with the requirements herein or any subsequent amendment hereto failure to properly obtain or maintain the required business license for a period of six months or more shall be considered an abandonment of the facility hmc   building permits prior to the construction of any telecommunications facility the applicant shall obtain the proper building permits road cut permits and other permits as required by the highland city municipal development land use  hmc   wireless telecommunications
